reasoning: Centrality: The critique targets the essay’s “threats could eat most value from moral trade” worry, which is an important modifier to the trade/compromise optimism but not the essay’s main conclusion (the essay also argues WAM-convergence is unlikely and that even threat-free trade can fail on linear/unbounded views). Strength: It offers a plausible counter-mechanism (deterrence/MAD and norm formation) but doesn’t engage key complications the essay relies on: asymmetric threat advantages, credible commitment/commitment races, extortion equilibria, and cases where retaliation is impossible/too costly; it also doesn’t address the essay’s point that even low probability of executed threats can dominate expected value under many axiologies. Correctness: Some points are reasonable (deterrence can stabilize; nuclear history suggests non-execution is common), but a major claim appears mistaken or at least backwards: altruists having less credible threats would generally make them easier extortion targets (less ability/willingness to retaliate), not “poor” ones. The leap from “threats are cheap” to “counter-threat capabilities will proliferate and deter” is also under-argued. Clarity is high and it stays focused with little dead weight.
title: Mutual threat capacity may create deterrent stability rather than fragility
